div1.p: In the United States District Court, for the Western District of Washington Norther Division
In The Matter of Chin Hing
#2857 Interrogatories to be propounded to Louis D. Post, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Labor., Washington, D. C.
1. Are you the Assistant Secretary of Labor, and if so, when were you appointed to such office?
2. Were you on duty at the Department of Labor on each of the following dated: September 24th, 1914, September 25th, 1914 and September 26th, 1914?
3. What office does Mr. J. B. Densmore hold in your Department, if any?

4.State whether it is or is not the custom for Mr. J. B. Densmore, the Solicitor for the Department of Labor, to consider and decide appeals in Chinese and immigration cases, as "Acting Secretary" of Labor, notwithstanding the fact that you or Secretary Wilson, or both of you, may be on duty at the time when Mr. Densmore asumes to act as Secretary?

5. Did you formerly excercise the functions of "Acting Secretary" in considering and deciding Chinese appeal cases, at any time when Mr. Densmore was on duty in the Department? If so, why or upon what authority were Chinese appeal cases taken from you and given to Mr. Densmore to decide, and when?

6. Have you been advised, officially or otherwise, of any ruling made by a Federal Court of the United States, that Mr. Densmore cannot lawfully decide Chinese appeal cases, as "Acting Secretary" if either the Secretary or Assistant Secretary of Labor or either of them shal be on duty in the Department of Labor at the time when Mr. Densmore assumes to so act?
7. If so, do you know whether Mr. Densmore had decided or continues to decide any Chinese appeal cases since such ruling?

8.Do you know whether or not Secretary Wilson has been absent from the Department for any lengthy period since this case or any other case in which the same question is involved, has been pending in court, and if so, when?
9. Were you or were you not the Acting Secretary during his abence, if he was absent?

10. Did you decide any Chinese appeal cases as Acting Secretary during Secretary Wilson's abseence, and if not, why not, and who did assume to act as Acting Secretary in his absence while you were present in the Department of Labor?

11. Did J. B. Densmore, in giving his ruling in any of the Chinese appeal cases which he either affirmed or reviewed while either you or Secretary Wilson were present in the Department of Labor, sign his name as "J. B. Densmore, Acting Secretary of Labor."?

12. Will you state on what date the ruling of "Acting Secretary" Densmore was made in the case of Ching Hing, in affirming the Order of Deportation, and whether or not on said date either you of Secretary Wilson, or both of you, were present in the Department of Labor?
